name: Dummy Deck
description: Sandbox for testing new technical phrases before migration.

cards.sideA: El texto esta escrito en primera persona.

sideB.text: The text is written in the first person.
The text is in the first person.
The writing is in the first person.

cards.note:
Use [written in] for passive voice structures.

~The text is written by first person~ is incorrect because we use the preposition 'in' to describe the perspective or voice. Use [written in].

cards.sideA: Pidele en el prompt que te responda en tercera persona.

sideB.text: Ask it in the prompt to reply in the third person.
Tell it to respond in the third person within the prompt.
In the prompt, ask for a response in the third person.
Ask it in the prompt to answer you in the third person.

cards.note:
When interacting with AI, [ask it to] is standard for commands.

~answer your in the third person~ is incorrect because 'your' is a possessive adjective and needs a noun. Use [answer you].

cards.sideA: Pidele que no te conteste en segunda persona.

sideB.text: Ask it not to answer you in the second person.
Tell it not to reply using the second person.
Ask for the response to not be in the second person.
Ask him not to answer you in the second person.

cards.note: Negative command: [Ask it not to] + [verb].

cards.sideA: ¿Que le pasa a el?

sideB.text: What is wrong with him?
What's going on with him?
What's happening to him?
What happens to him?

cards.note:
**[160]**

[What's wrong with...] is the most common way to ask about someone's state.

~What does he happen?~ is not valid because 'happen' is an intransitive verb where the subject is the event, not the person. Use [What happened to him?].

cards.sideA: ¿Que le paso a ella?

sideB.text: What happened to her?
What went on with her?
What was the matter with her?

cards.note:
**[160]**

[What happened] is the standard past tense for occurrences.

~What did it happen to her?~ is incorrect because 'happen' is intransitive and doesn't use the 'it' dummy subject in this specific question structure. Use [What happened to her?].

cards.sideA: No se como se dice ese oficio.

sideB.text: I don't know how to say that job.
I'm not sure how to call that trade.
I don't know the word for that profession.

cards.note: [Trade] or [Job] are natural for 'oficio'.

cards.sideA: (Solo puedes arrastrar y soltar los archivos aquí).

sideB.text: You can just drag and drop the files here.
You can only drag and drop files in this area.
Simply drag and drop your files here.

cards.note: [Drag and drop] is the standard UI terminology.

cards.sideA: (Usa la función de arrastrar y soltar para subir tu foto).

sideB.text: Use the drag-and-drop feature to upload your photo.
Use drag and drop to submit your picture.
You can use the drag-and-drop tool for your photo.

cards.note: When used as an adjective, it is hyphenated: [drag-and-drop] feature.

cards.sideA: (Este sitio web tiene una interfaz de arrastrar y soltar muy fácil).

sideB.text: This website has a very easy drag-and-drop interface.
The drag-and-drop interface on this site is very simple.
This site offers a user-friendly drag-and-drop UI.
This website has a very easy drag-and-drop UI.

cards.note: [User-friendly] is a common way to say something is easy to use.

cards.sideA: Un embedding convierte palabras en una lista de números.

sideB.text: An embedding turns words into a list of numbers.
Embeddings transform text into numerical lists.
An embedding converts language into a sequence of numbers.
An embedding transforms words into a list of numbers.

cards.note:
**[146]**

[Turns into] or [Converts into] are perfect for data transformations.

~transforms words in a list~ is incorrect for describing a conversion. Use [turns words into] or [transforms words into].

cards.sideA: Los embeddings representan el texto como coordenadas.

sideB.text: Embeddings represent text as coordinates.
Embeddings treat text as spatial coordinates.
Text is represented as coordinates through embeddings.

cards.note: [Represent as] is the standard technical term.

cards.sideA: Un vector es una lista de números llamada arreglo.

sideB.text: A vector is a list of numbers called an array.
Vectors are lists of numbers known as arrays.
An array is a list of numbers that represents a vector.
A vector is a list of numbers which is called an array.

cards.note:
[Called] or [Known as] are used to define terms.

~which are called array~ has subject-verb agreement issues (a list is...). Use [which is called an array] or [known as an array].

cards.sideA: Los vectores representan la ubicación exacta de un concepto.

sideB.text: Vectors represent the exact location of a concept.
Vectors show the precise position of a concept.
A vector maps the exact location of an idea.

cards.note:
[Maps] is a high-level verb for representing locations/relationships.

~ubication~ is a false friend from the Spanish 'ubicación'. Use [location].

cards.sideA: La búsqueda semántica busca el significado en lugar de palabras clave exactas.

sideB.text: Semantic search looks for meaning instead of exact keywords.
Semantic search focuses on intent rather than just keywords.
Instead of keywords, semantic search identifies the meaning.
Semantic search seeks meaning instead of exact keywords.

cards.note: [Instead of] is used to contrast two methods.

cards.sideA: La búsqueda semántica conecta 'abogado' con 'leyes' automáticamente.

sideB.text: Semantic search connects 'lawyer' with 'laws' automatically.
Semantic search links 'lawyer' and 'laws' by itself.
The system automatically associates 'lawyer' with 'laws'.

cards.note: [Associates with] is a formal synonym for 'connects'.

cards.sideA: RAG obliga a la IA a consultar una biblioteca antes de responder.

sideB.text: RAG forces the AI to check a library before answering.
RAG makes the AI look up data before responding.
With RAG, the AI must consult a knowledge base first.
RAG forces the AI to query a library before answering.

cards.note:
[Knowledge base] is the technical term for the 'biblioteca' in RAG.

~ensures the AI to check~ is grammatically incorrect. 'Ensure' should be followed by a 'that' clause. Use [forces the AI to check].

cards.sideA: RAG evita que la IA invente hechos.

sideB.text: RAG prevents the AI from making up facts.
RAG stops the AI from hallucinating facts.
RAG keeps the AI from inventing information.

cards.note:
[Hallucinating] is the industry term for an AI inventing facts.

~avoids the AI from making up facts~ is incorrect; 'avoid' is followed by a gerund directly. ~prevents the AI make up facts~ is missing the preposition 'from'. Use [prevents the AI from making up].

cards.sideA: RAG combina un motor de búsqueda con un modelo de lenguaje.

sideB.text: RAG combines a search engine with a language model.
RAG merges a search engine and a language model.
RAG is a combination of a search engine and an LLM.

cards.note: [LLM] stands for Large Language Model.

cards.sideA: Un pipeline es una secuencia de pasos automatizados.

sideB.text: A pipeline is a sequence of automated steps.
Pipelines are series of automated actions.
A pipeline refers to a chain of automated processes.

cards.note: [Chain of] is a good alternative for 'secuencia'.

cards.sideA: Los datos fluyen a través del pipeline de principio a fin.

sideB.text: Data flows through the pipeline from start to finish.
Information travels the pipeline from beginning to end.
Data goes through the entire pipeline.
Data flows through the pipeline from end to end.
Data flows through the pipeline from start to end.

cards.note:
[From start to finish] is the idiomatic way to say 'de principio a fin'.

[From start to end] is synonymous with [from start to finish]. However, [from end to end] implies covering the entire length or span, often translated as 'de extremo a extremo'.

cards.sideA: Los pipelines ayudan a organizar flujos de trabajo de IA complejos.

sideB.text: Pipelines help organize complex AI workflows.
Pipelines are useful for managing complex AI workflows.
Complex AI workflows are organized using pipelines.

cards.note: [Workflows] is the standard term for 'flujos de trabajo'.

cards.sideA: Un cluster es un grupo de servidores trabajando juntos.

sideB.text: A cluster is a group of servers working together.
Clusters are sets of servers operating in unison.
A group of servers working as one is called a cluster.

cards.note: [Working together] is simple and clear.

cards.sideA: Un cluster asegura que el sistema siga en línea si un servidor falla.

sideB.text: A cluster ensures the system stays online if one server fails.
Clusters guarantee uptime even if a server goes down.
A cluster keeps the system up if there is a server failure.

cards.note:
[Uptime] and [Stays online] are key for infrastructure.

~keeps online~ is not idiomatic. Use [stays online] or [remains online].

cards.sideA: LN en una variable significa 'Local number'.

sideB.text: LN in a variable stands for 'Local number'.
LN in a variable means 'Local number'.
The prefix LN usually represents 'Local number'.

cards.note: [Stands for] is commonly used for acronyms.

cards.sideA: La letra S significa Éxito

sideB.text: The letter S means Success.
The letter S stands for Success.
S represents Success in this context.

cards.note: Common flag in programming logic.

cards.sideA: La letra E significa Error

sideB.text: The letter E means Error.
The letter E stands for Error.
E is used to indicate an Error.

cards.note: Standard error flag.

cards.sideA: La letra U significa Error Inesperado

sideB.text: The letter U means Unexpected Error.
The letter U stands for Unexpected Error.
U represents an Unexpected Error status.

cards.note: [Unexpected] is used for errors not handled by specific logic.

cards.sideA: El código 200 significa Éxito

sideB.text: Code 200 means Success.
The 200 code represents a successful request.
A 200 status code indicates Success.

cards.note: Standard HTTP status for OK.

cards.sideA: El código 400 significa Error

sideB.text: Code 400 means Error.
The 400 code indicates a Bad Request or Error.
Status code 400 stands for a client-side Error.
The 400 code means Error.
400 code means Error.

cards.note: [Bad Request] is the official name for HTTP 400.

cards.sideA: La letra A significa Activo

sideB.text: The letter A means Active.
The letter A stands for Active.
A represents the Active status.

cards.note:
Common flag for database statuses.

~The A letter means Active~ is unnatural because in English, the identifying name usually follows the category noun. Use [The letter A].

cards.sideA: La letra Y significa Verdadero

sideB.text: The letter Y means True.
The letter Y stands for Yes or True.
Y represents a True boolean value.

cards.note: [Y] is usually 'Yes', representing 'True'.

cards.sideA: La letra N significa Falso o No.

sideB.text: The letter N stands for False or No.
The letter N means No or False.
N represents a False value.

cards.note: [N] is usually 'No', representing 'False'.

cards.sideA: La letra F significa Falso

sideB.text: The letter F stands for False.
The letter F means False.
F is used to represent a False boolean.

cards.note:
Direct boolean representation.

~The F letter~ is incorrect word order. In English, we place the specific identifier after the category. Use [The letter F].

cards.sideA: El record creado en otro paquete esta siendo poblado ahi

sideB.text: The record created in another package is being populated there.
That's where the record from a different package gets populated.
The record from another package is being filled in there.
The created record in another package is being populated there.

cards.note: [Is being populated] is the technical way to say data is being inserted/filled.

cards.sideA: Los campos del record de otro paquete estan populandose ahi

sideB.text: The fields of the record from another package are being populated there.
That's where the record fields from another package are filled.
Record fields from a different package are being populated right there.
The fields of the record from another package are populated there.

cards.note: [Fields] are the specific attributes within a [Record].

cards.sideA: Esto está fuera del alcance de mi trabajo.

sideB.text: This is out of the scope of my work.
This is outside my scope of work.
This falls outside the scope of my job.

cards.note: In professional contexts, [scope] refers to the boundaries of a project or role.

cards.sideA: El alcance del problema es enorme.

sideB.text: The scope of the problem is huge.
The scale of the issue is massive.
The magnitude of the problem is enormous.

cards.note:
[Scope] can also describe the extent or size of a technical challenge.

~The scope problem is huge~ is not valid because 'scope' requires the preposition [of] to connect it to the noun being described. Use [The scope of the problem].

cards.sideA: ¿Esto entra dentro del alcance del proyecto?

sideB.text: Is this within the project scope?
Does this fall under the project scope?
Is this in scope for the project?
Is this included in the scope of the project?
Is this in the scope of the project?

cards.note: Use [in scope] or [within scope] to confirm if a task belongs to the current plan.

cards.sideA: Arrastra el archivo hacia la carpeta.

sideB.text: Drag the file to the folder.
Drag the file into the folder.
Drag and drop the file into the folder.

cards.note: When moving items in a UI, use [drag to] for destination or [drag into] for containment.

cards.sideA: Se requiere que lo hagas si o si.

sideB.text: You are required to do it no matter what.
You must do it at all costs.
You're required to do it, period.
It requires you to do it no matter what.

cards.note:
The Spanish expression [Sí o sí] does not have a literal translation like ~yes or yes~.

To communicate this absolute necessity, English uses phrases like [no matter what], [at all costs], or the word [period] at the end of a sentence to indicate that there is no room for argument.

~It requires you do it no matter what~ is missing the particle 'to'. The verb 'require' follows the structure [require someone to do something].

cards.sideA: Deberemos hacerlo si o si.

sideB.text: We'll have to do it regardless.
We must get it done one way or another.
We are going to have to do it no matter what.
We must do it no matter what.

cards.note:
The Spanish expression [Sí o sí] does not have a literal translation like ~yes or yes~.

When [sí o sí] implies that something will happen despite obstacles, English speakers use [regardless] or [one way or another]. These emphasize that the result is inevitable.

~We must do it yes or yes~ is a common non-native error that should be avoided.

cards.sideA: Me dio risa

sideB.text: It made me laugh.
I found it funny.
I cracked up.
I laughed a lot.

cards.note:
**[39]**

In English, emotions and reactions are rarely 'given' (dar).

Instead of ~It gave me laugh~, we use a causative structure: [It made me laugh] or describe the internal state: [I found it funny].

[I cracked up] is a very natural phrasal verb used when something makes you laugh suddenly and intensely.

~I got laughed~ is incorrect because 'laugh' is an intransitive verb in this context; it doesn't describe a state you 'get'.

cards.sideA: Me dio hambre

sideB.text: I got hungry.
I started feeling hungry.
I'm getting hungry.
It made me hungry.

cards.note:
**[39]**

In English, emotions and reactions are rarely 'given' (dar).

Physical sensations like hunger or thirst use the verb [get] to indicate a change of state. 

~It gave me hunger~ is incorrect. Use [I got hungry] to describe the moment the sensation began.

~It made me hunger~ is incorrect because 'hunger' is a noun; you must use the adjective [hungry] in this structure.

cards.sideA: Me dio rabia

sideB.text: It made me angry.
I got so mad.
It was so frustrating.

cards.note:
**[39]**

In English, emotions and reactions are rarely 'given' (dar).

For intense negative emotions, English uses [make me] + adjective. 

~It gave me anger~ is not idiomatic. Use [It made me angry] to focus on the cause, or [I got mad] to focus on your reaction.

~I angered a lot~ is not natural. While 'anger' can be a verb, it is almost always used with an object. To describe your own feeling, use [I got angry] or [I was very angry].

cards.sideA: Me hizo feliz aquello.

sideB.text: That made me happy.
It made me happy.
That made me feel happy.

cards.note:
**[39]**

In English, we use the causative [make] + [object] + [adjective] to describe how something affects our emotions.

~It made me happy that~ is incomplete; [that] should be the subject [That made me happy] or refer to a specific clause.

cards.sideA: Me puso nervioso lo que ellos dijeron.

sideB.text: What they said made me nervous.
What they said made me feel nervous.
It made me nervous what they said.

cards.note:
**[39]**

[What they said] acts as the subject that caused the state of being [nervous].

cards.sideA: Me dio asco esa cosa.

sideB.text: That thing made me sick.
That thing made me feel sick.
That made me feel disgusted.
I got sick with that thing.

cards.note:
**[39]**

To express 'dar asco', English often uses [made me sick] or [made me feel disgusted].

cards.sideA: Me dio sueño la pelicula.

sideB.text: The movie made me sleepy.
It made me feel sleepy watching that movie.
That movie made me feel drowsy.

cards.note:
**[39]**

[Sleepy] is the adjective for 'tener sueño'. In this case, the movie is the cause.

~It made me feel sleepy the movie~ is incorrect word order; the subject [the movie] should come first: [The movie made me feel sleepy].

cards.sideA: Me hizo preguntarme eso que escuche.

sideB.text: What I heard made me wonder.
It made me wonder what I heard.
That made me question things after I heard it.

cards.note:
**[39]**

[Wonder] is the base verb here. Remember that after [make], we use the base form without 'to'.

~What I heard, it made me wonder~ is redundant because [What I heard] is already the subject; you should not add [it] after it.

cards.sideA: Me hizo pensar.

sideB.text: It made me think.
That made me think.
It gave me food for thought.

cards.note:
**[39]**

[Food for thought] is a common idiom meaning something that provides mental stimulus or interest.

cards.sideA: Me hizo sentir mejor.

sideB.text: It made me feel better.
That made me feel better.
It made me feel a bit better.

cards.note:
**[39]**

[Feel better] is the result caused by 'it' or 'that'.

cards.sideA: Me hizo quedar mal ella.

sideB.text: She made me look bad.
She made me look incompetent.
Her actions made me look bad.

cards.note:
**[39]**

[To look bad] is the standard idiom for 'quedar mal' in a social or professional sense.

cards.sideA: "nada que ver!" (idiom)

sideB.text: Not related at all!
Zero connection!
Completely unrelated!
That has nothing to do with it!

cards.note: [Nothing to do with it] is the most literal way to translate the sentiment of 'nada que ver' regarding topics.

cards.sideA: Usa una tabla de consulta para acelerar el proceso.

sideB.text: Use a lookup table to speed up the process.
The system failed during the database lookup.
Use a query table to accelerate the process.
Utilize a lookup table to optimize speed.

cards.note: [Lookup table] is the technical term for a table used to map or retrieve values quickly.

cards.sideA: Tenemos varias tablas de consulta para ese proposito.

sideB.text: We have several lookup tables for that purpose.
We have multiple lookup tables for that goal.
There are several lookup tables for that specific purpose.

cards.note: [Several] and [Multiple] are natural ways to say 'varias'.

cards.sideA: Se requiere probar la función en el dispositivo real.

sideB.text: It is required to test the feature on a real device.
You are required to test the function on an actual device.
Testing the feature on the real device is required.

cards.note:
[Actual device] or [Real device] distinguish physical hardware from an emulator or simulator.

~It requires to test the feature on a real device~ is incorrect because [require] is not used as a dummy subject verb; use [It is required to test] or [Testing requires...].

cards.sideA: Chile está tres horas detrás del UTC.

sideB.text: Chile is three hours behind UTC.
Chile is UTC-3.
Chile lags three hours behind UTC.

cards.note:
**[177]**

Use [behind] to describe a negative offset from the UTC baseline.

cards.sideA: Canadá está dos horas detrás de Chile en el UTC

sideB.text: Canada is two hours behind Chile in UTC.
Canada lags two hours behind Chile on the UTC scale.
There is a two-hour UTC difference between Canada and Chile.

cards.sideA: El servidor de correo usa la hora UTC.

sideB.text: The mail server uses UTC time.
The email server is set to UTC.
The mail server runs on UTC.
The email server uses UTC time.

cards.note:
**[177]**

Servers typically [run on] or are [set to] UTC to maintain a consistent log timeline.

~The mail server uses UTC hour~ is not standard because [UTC] is already a time standard; we say [UTC time] or simply [UTC].

cards.sideA: UTC es el punto de partida para la hora mundial.

sideB.text: UTC is the starting point for world time.
UTC is the global time baseline.
UTC serves as the starting point for world time.

cards.sideA: UTC-3 significa tres horas detrás del punto cero.

sideB.text: UTC-3 means three hours behind the zero point.
UTC-3 signifies being three hours behind point zero.
A UTC-3 offset means three hours behind the zero baseline.

cards.sideA: Chile usa el UTC-3 en verano y UTC-4 en invierno.

sideB.text: Chile uses UTC-3 in summer and UTC-4 in winter.
Chile switches between UTC-3 in summer and UTC-4 in winter.
Chile's offset is UTC-3 during summer and UTC-4 during winter.

cards.sideA: No se tanto como me gustaria.

sideB.text: I don't know as much as I'd like.
I don't know as much as I would like to.
My knowledge isn't as deep as I'd like it to be.

cards.note: Use [As much as] for comparisons of equality (or lack thereof).

cards.sideA: Apenas estoy sobreviviendo en las reuniones.

sideB.text: I'm barely surviving in the meetings.
I am just getting by in the meetings.
I'm barely keeping my head above water in the meetings.

cards.note: [Keeping my head above water] is an idiom meaning to just barely manage or survive a difficult situation.

cards.sideA: ... pero no tanto como me gustaria.

sideB.text: ...but not as much as I'd like.
...but not as much as I would like.
...but not to the extent I'd like.
...but not as much as I'd like to.

cards.note: [To the extent] is a formal way to say 'al grado' or 'tanto'.

cards.sideA: ¿Que hace esa opcion?

sideB.text: What does that option do?
What's the function of that option?
What does that setting do?

cards.note: Standard [What does ... do?] structure for inquiring about functionality.

cards.sideA: ¿Que hace este fragmento?

sideB.text: What does this snippet do?
What does this fragment do?
What is the purpose of this snippet?

cards.note: [Snippet] is the standard developer term for a small 'fragmento' of code.

cards.sideA: ... pero no tanto como quisiera.

sideB.text: ...but not as much as I'd want.
...but not as much as I would like.
...but not as much as I wish.
...but not as much as I'd want to.
...but not as much as I'd like to.

cards.note: Using [Wish] adds a slight tone of regret to the desire.

cards.sideA: Quisiera que fuera más.

sideB.text: I wish it were more.
I'd like it to be more.
I want it to be more.

cards.note:
**[40]**

After 'I wish', we use the subjunctive [were] for hypothetical states.

cards.sideA: Me gustaria que eso fuera mejor.

sideB.text: I'd like that to be better.
I wish that were better.
I would like that to be improved.

cards.note:
Structure: [I'd like] + [object] + [to be].

~I'd like that would be better~ and ~I'd like that will be better~ are incorrect because [would like] requires the [object + to + verb] structure.
